video.title: Indiana Jones and the Great Circle | Fully Ramblomatic

captions.text:
Well, I&#39;ve had my expectations confounded. 
But then people always expect from me being

tall that I would have an at least average-sized 
penis, so it&#39;s only fair. There were so many red

flags on this game, you&#39;d think it&#39;d fallen to the 
communists. First, it comes out in mid-December,

which is frequently a sign that the publisher at 
least has low expectations and are hoping to fling

it out while everyone&#39;s distracted by holidays and 
then leg it to the car with their shit umbrellas

up. Secondly, it&#39;s Indiana Jones, and the last 
Indiana Jones movie was two prolapsed bladders

in a carrying case rated only for one prolapsed 
bladder. Much like a certain other Lucasfilm

franchise that increasingly aptly rhymes with 
&quot;snores,&quot; shit Indiana Jones now outweighs good

Indiana Jones, which consists of Raiders of the 
Lost Ark, Last Crusade, and the less racist bits

of Temple of Doom. I really expected Indiana Jones 
and the Great Circle to fizzle out on the world

stage like an enthusiastic conductor&#39;s careless 
act of flatulence, so imagine my surprise when

I played it and found it to be resoundingly okay. 
With Troy Baker doing a remarkably good impression

of a young Harrison Ford, really nailing the way 
he always talked like his front teeth had been

stuck together by a carelessly bitten toffee.
I&#39;m not going nuts for the game like some of my

peers are; I would describe it as a case of 
doing very little new but everything right,

like an unusually well-put-together plate of 
beans on toast. Worcestershire Sauce and a

little sprinkle of Parmesan; that&#39;s what does it 
for me. Indiana Jones and the Circular Argument

comes to us from MachineGames, who, after 
Wolfenstein: Youngblood, had nowhere to go

but up and a lot of sick they needed to launder 
out of the bedsheets. It&#39;s a first-person action

adventure stealth &#39;em up in a Dishonored-y sort 
of area that divides its time between bullying

Nazis and solving remarkably functional puzzles 
and platforming challenges in ancient tombs,

no territory that hasn&#39;t been thoroughly covered 
by the likes of Tomb Raider and Uncharted in the

course of ripping off Indiana Jones, which I 
guess is only fair. The plot is Indiana Jones

wakes up one morning to find Tony Todd robbing 
his museum, and before he can tell him how much

he enjoyed his work in the Final Destination 
films, he runs away, kicking off a global quest

for an ancient secret that actually feels very 
convincingly like a classic Indiana Jones film.

Probably because it rips off half of them. You 
know how in the Last Crusade, Indy has to search

for a crusader&#39;s tomb while being hunted by a 
secret society trying to keep it under wraps

in Venice? Well, the first bit of Great Circle 
involves searching for a crusader&#39;s tomb while

being hunted by a secret society trying to keep it 
under wraps in Rome. And you know how in Raiders,

Indy infiltrates a Nazi dig site in Cairo 
to find the mystical Staff of Ra? Well,

now we infiltrate a Nazi dig site in Giza to find 
the mystical idol of Ra. I&#39;d almost go as far to

call this a &quot;soft adaptation,&quot; if such a thing 
exists, but I can&#39;t fault the game for sticking to

a winning formula: globetrotting, ancient tombs, 
magical realism, spunky redoubtable love interest,

punch a lot of Nazis in the face. It&#39;s a formula 
that adapts well to video games; I forgot to

mention Fate of Atlantis back there when I was 
listing &quot;good&quot; Indiana Jones, so I&#39;m bringing it

up now in the hope of humiliating all the little 
twats who ran to the comment section before

finishing the video. That was a point-and-click 
adventure, but turns out Indiana Jones also adapts

remarkably well to stealth action gameplay.
At least he does when I&#39;m controlling him. I

sneak through some hidden tunnels, poke my head 
up through the floor of the Nazi command post,

look around and see a dirty great Nazi sitting on 
the toilet, with whom I make startled eye contact

over his copy of Fascist Dictator Monthly. 
&quot;Boy, this really does feel like I organically

created a moment from an Indiana Jones film,&quot; I 
reflect as I beat him to unconsciousness with the

toilet brush. Combat has this deliberately 
scrappy, improvisational feel with its use

of ample disposable weaponry. If it&#39;s solid and 
at least a foot long and not one of the turds I

produce after binging on oatmeal flapjacks, then 
chances are you can pick it up and knock Nazis

unconscious with it. You can also employ classic 
Indiana Jones fisticuffs, but that tends to be

mashy and unsatisfying, and if the enemy Nazis 
have guns, don&#39;t even bother sticking around,

just employ classic Indiana Jones &quot;running away 
like a scared little girl&quot; tactics. All told,

this is one of those games where it&#39;s fun—and 
actually kind of on brand—to fuck up. You don&#39;t

feel bad about failing at stealth and having 
to start shooting because they&#39;re Nazis,

fuck &#39;em. Kill as many as you like, then 
really rub it in by eating all their biscuits.

The game&#39;s hub-based and laid out in a series 
of mini open worlds full of secret collectibles,

side quests, and hidden traversal paths. And 
one thing I particularly like is that the side

quests all feel like they progress the central 
plot rather than distract from it. It&#39;s like,

stick to the critical path and you&#39;ll play through 
what feels like a classic Indy film. Do all the

side quests, and you get the Director&#39;s Cut of 
the same Indy film with all the deleted scenes

put back in. And I&#39;d recommend relishing 
the game while it lasts, &#39;cos the ending

was disappointing. It&#39;s back to formula again; 
it&#39;s beat for beat the end of Raiders, basically,

and what passed for the final boss fight was just 
some fisticuffs with a twat, and as established,

the fisticuffs absolutely aren&#39;t the game&#39;s strong 
point, especially when the twat has a bunch of

new moves that change the rules we&#39;ve gotten used 
to. Would&#39;ve been far more representative of the

gameplay experience up to that point if the final 
showdown had taken the form of a desperate toilet

brush fencing contest. In fact, now that I&#39;m 
talking about it, Indiana Jones and the Circling

of the Drain is a game with a great first act but 
which struggles to keep the bar at that level.

Like a Cornish pasty where all the meat&#39;s been 
packed down one end. The first hub area in the

Vatican is fucking great. Full of things to do 
and see and secret paths—I&#39;d just be exploring

randomly, trying not to make eye contact with 
Italian fascists, pass through a door, and wham,

I&#39;m in the actual Sistine fucking Chapel; I&#39;ve 
been tricked into learning something. The rest

of the game&#39;s fine: the set pieces are piecy, the 
evil Nazis are evil, the spunky redoubtable love

interest is veritably brimming with redoubtable 
spunk, and Indy himself chews on his toffees

with utmost consistency, but while the other hub 
areas—such as &quot;square mile of desert&quot; and &quot;square

mile of jungle&quot;—merely do the job, the Vatican 
does the job, stays late after closing time,

and leaves little hypoallergenic gift baskets 
on everybody&#39;s desks. Not that the rest of the

game lacks for highlights, it&#39;s just... well, 
let&#39;s go back to turd analogies. It starts out

with a transcendently satisfying initial release 
you&#39;ve been holding in for the last two hours,

then most of the rest of it is a businesslike 
going through of the motions, as it were,

with some little flair-ups of satisfaction as 
you tackle stubborn bits and some pain right

at the very end when you remember that morning 
you accidentally swallowed a horse chestnut.
